column47: Human Resources & Payroll System
column48:
The Human Resources & Payroll System Project 

The University’s current HR & Payroll System was implemented in 2004.  In 2015 the University undertook and external review of the HR & Payroll systems provision with the purpose of identifying the best way forward for HR & Payroll technological provision.  The review focussed on the need to underpin the University’s People Strategy 2015-2020 (see Appendix 1) by the provision of simple, efficient, technology enabled processes (aspiring towards self-service).  The People Strategy further supports the University’s Strategic Framework goal ‘to ensure that [the University] is an inspiring place to work, where people are able to develop and realise their potential within a friendly and professional learning community’. 

Following an analysis of available options, looking at both current system provision and offline processes, the review recommended that the University goes to market for HR and Payroll as an integrated product.  

Current State

The University’s current HR & Payroll System is part of the integrated Agresso Business World product (ABW) provided by Unit 4, used also for finance and purchasing processes within the University.  In addition, the Human Resources & Organisation Development department (HR & OD) use several additional, non-integrated systems for other processes including:

•	An in-house staff training database 
•	i-grasp for e-recruitment processes 
•	A hosted solution called VT2000 for the management of hourly paid academic staff

Vision

At the organisational level, our vision is that a new HR and Payroll system will help to deliver one of the key elements of the People Strategy – “Simple, efficient processes that are technology enabled”.  The University primary position is to procure a single technical solution for the capture of full employee lifecycle activity. However, if necessary, best of breed solutions might be considered where the desired functionality cannot be achieved in one solution.  The University’s vision for the new system is that it will deliver:

•	A single technical solution for the capture of full employee lifecycle information
•	A focus on maximising manager and employee self-service
•	Sophisticated and robust data and reporting capabilities, including data analytics, to drive decision making
•	The maximisation of operational efficiency through lean and efficient business processes
•	Excellent value for money
•	Effective and robust interfaces with other University systems

column47: Soft Market Testing on potential future procurement options for the Electric Theatre
column48:
Guildford Borough Council wishes to secure a strong vibrant future for The Electric Theatre. It is an important entertainment venue in the town and provides a prominent facility for community theatre.
We recognise that a skilled operator must have sufficient headroom to put together a commercially sustainable programme of entertainments for which there is strong demand. Alongside this, we would like to see the venue remain as a performing arts facility with community use. This was agreed by the Council’s Executive in April 2016 and the report can be found here: http://www2.guildford.gov.uk/councilmeetings/documents/s4920/Item%2006%20-%20Electric%20Theatre%20and%20YAT%20Working%20Group.pdf. 
Following a public consultation around the future operation of the Theatre ‘community use’ has been identified largely as ‘performances, theatre, festivals and education’.  
We wish to consult skilled operators in this field as to how these aims can be balanced for The Electric Theatre in the future.
To this end, we are conducting soft market testing to garner your views on these aspects plus other important considerations including the procurement route.
Thus, the Council may choose a concession or lease route to secure the future of the Theatre.
We are keen to control your financial and time involvement in bidding for the work, but at the same time believe that a procurement route with the opportunity to talk about risks which worry you and to give the opportunity to negotiate, would give a better result for both parties.
Amanda Hargreaves will be project managing the procurement process on behalf of the Council. She has left her previous role of General Manager of The Electric Theatre and is no longer involved in its day to day operation. Her focus is solely on delivering a fair and open procurement process for the Theatre. 
Applying

If you would like to see us to discuss this opportunity then please write, in no more than one thousand words, describing your interest in the procurement, your past experience in the field and the points you would like to discuss.
We plan to undertake soft market testing on 3 consecutive days which will occur close to the centre of Guildford in the date range between July and September. Each party would have two hours with a common agenda and the meeting will be held in Guildford.
If you are not seen please rest assured that this will not disadvantage you in any forthcoming formal procurement. All parties that express an interest will receive feedback from the soft market testing event before an Official Journal of the European Union notice is published (marking the start of the formal procurement procedure).
Please send your submission to amanda.hargreaves@guildford.gov.uk [Project Manager] and vincent.hunt@guildford.gov.uk [Procurement] 

by 6th July 2016. Any clarification questions to these e- mail addresses please.

column47: NKp46+CD3+ cells as a Novel Target for Vaccines Against Bovine TB
column48:
The Morrison and Vordermeier laboratories have recently identified a novel NKp46+CD3+ non-conventional T-cell
population in cattle and demonstrated that a subset of these cells recognise phosphatidylinositol mannosides (PIMs - a
group of membrane bound lipids) from Mb. In this project we propose to i) examine NKp46+CD3+ T-cell responses during
a BCG-immunisation/Mb-challenge study so as to gain some insights into the role of lipid-specific T-cells in bTB and ii)
explore the breadth of lipids from TB that act as antigens for bovine T-cells and evaluate their potential as vaccine
antigens. Specifically we aim to address the following questions:
1. What are the quantitative and kinetic characteristics of the NKp46+CD3+ T-cell response following BCG vaccination and
subsequent exposure to M.
bovis?
2. What are the functions of NKp46+CD3+ T-cells recognising mycobacteria?
3. Which mycobacterial lipids are recognised by NKp46+CD3+ (and other) bovine T-cells?
4. Can vaccination with mycobacterial lipid extracts elicit NKp46+CD3+ T-cell responses in vivo?
The combined results of the proposed studies will provide the fundamental basic immunological data to determine if
inclusion of lipid antigens has the potential to enhance the immunogenicity and protective efficacy of new bTB vaccines.
We also will perform analyses to define if lipid antigens could be used as novel DIVA reagents.

column47: Upton Park Heritage Wall Rebuild
column48:
The Homes and Communities Agency wish to appoint a contractor to undertake the reconstruction and remedial work to an existing heritage wall located in Upton, Northampton.
The wall’s longstanding presence, since the Medieval times, has rendered sections of the wall liable to collapse. The construction works subsequently involve the rebuilding of the collapsed sections of wall. These works include the exposing of existing foundations, inspection of the structural integrity of the exposed foundations and collapsed wall material, rebuild of the wall and subsequent aftercare treatment works.
The construction of the wall shall be in line with The English Heritage Trust regeneration expectations as well as being comparable to recent rebuilt sections of the wall.   
General works will include:
•	Assessment of current state of wall/materials
•	Procurement of materials
•	Re-build of the wall
•	Producing construction drawings
•	Producing method statements
•	Producing material submittal (inclusive of bond patterns for approval)
•	Provide a test panel for approval
The contractor will also be responsible for maintaining the surrounding environment to the existing standard and repairing any damages made due to the transportation of construction materials/plant.

Additional information: The closing time for tenders is 1pm.

All discussions, meetings and communications will be conducted in English.  

The contract will be subject to English law.  Tenders and all supporting documents must be priced in GBP and all payments under the contract will be made in GBP.
